Climate change will affect the productivity of major crops, including maize, the most important staple food for more than 35% of the world’s population. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability to quantify how maize yields will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. The probability that the top four maize-exporting countries have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

Herbivores are a major component of ecosystems, and the diversity of herbivores is often high. However, the diversity of herbivore species within a community is not necessarily reflected in the number of species that are observed feeding on the same plant species. This is known as the “paradox of the majority,” and it is thought to be caused by competition for the same resources. We show that this is not the case for large mammalian herbivores, and that the diversity of species within a community is reflected in the diversity of diets. This suggests that the diversity of herbivore species may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses are planning to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but we find that many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris in the ocean is a major environmental concern. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of plastic debris in the ocean interior. The fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of presolar silicon carbide grains is one of the most important unsolved problems in astrophysics. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We conclude that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The results are important for the understanding of the formation of the Solar System. (Show more)

The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, and there are signs of stabilization and more effective management in recent years. We also show that the ability to increase metabolic power is limited by the mother’s metabolic power. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the limits to reproductive output and a framework for future research on the evolution of reproductive output. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. The disease is characterized by the presence of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. We present here an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues of the body. It is the primary regulator of vascular function and the first line of defense against infection and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform a variety of functions. The endothelium is able to integrate information from multiple sources and coordinate its responses. The communication network between the cells of the endothelium is the key to its function. Here, the nature of the communication network between endothelial cells has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The results reveal that the endothelium is a highly connected, small-world network with a high degree of synchronizability. The network is effective for both local and global communication and is able to rapidly and robustly respond to stimuli. These findings provide a detailed description of the communication network between endothelial cells and reveal the mechanisms by which they coordinate their activities. The findings have implications for understanding the function of the endothelium and for the development of new therapies for cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of public health surveillance signals, as well as many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The data are available for free, and we hope that they will be useful to researchers, policy makers, and the general public.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a structural basis for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation gating in the K+ channel family. Finally, it provides a structural basis for the development of potassium channel blockers. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the field of potassium channel research.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to the health of the host. The role of fungi in the gut microbiome is less well understood, but they are known to be important in the digestion of plant material. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi synthesize a diverse range of natural products, including antibiotics, antimicrobials, and other bioactive compounds. These results support the idea that fungi may be important in the development of new therapeutics for human health.

Anxiety is a common feature of psychiatric disorders, and social anxiety is one of the most prevalent. However, the mechanisms underlying social anxiety are not fully understood. Here we show that anxiety influences social dominance in rats and identify an important role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We also show that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, enhances brain energy metabolism and prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with desired behaviors is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures, which are digitally designed to seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors. The synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors, some of which are unachievable by a single material. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The proposed strategy can also be extended to design and manufacture other complex structures. This work provides a general approach to design and manufacture mechanical devices with desired behaviors. It is expected to have a significant impact on the development of mechanical devices in various fields.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythrocytes is developmentally regulated and is influenced by the transcription factor BCL11A. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in erythroid cells and that its expression is developmentally regulated. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 can reprogram the hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroid cells. This is achieved by reduced expression of the adult hemoglobin alpha chain and increased expression of the fetal hemoglobin gamma chain. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. The results also suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a heterogeneous disease, and the development of resistance to therapy is a major obstacle to successful treatment. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, which is highly relevant to cancer. We also identified a therapeutic strategy that can overcome this resistance. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapies for cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the management of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2) blockers. These drugs are associated with the development of heart failure. We show that these drugs promote vascular remodeling through activation of the STIM/ORAI pathway. Our findings may help to understand the mechanism of action of these drugs and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of heart failure. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. It is also able to achieve state-of-the-art results in several problems. The proposed architecture is a general framework that can be applied to many problems. It is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice. The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). Over the Quaternary, we observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. The use of electronic devices, such as tablets and smartphones, within 1 h of bedtime has become increasingly common. This practice has been shown to suppress melatonin, phase-delay the circadian clock, and reduce sleep quality. However, the impact of such devices on the following day’s performance and health is unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device for 1 h before bedtime suppresses melatonin, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces the next-morning alertness and performance of healthy young adults. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. CTLA-4 is a well-known regulator of immune responses, but its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is not fully understood. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice results in the development of a variety of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that the function of CTLA-4 is not limited to the early phase of immune responses, but also in the development of autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles and to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification. We also traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, which is a major challenge for plants and animals. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes. These results have important implications for understanding the evolution of plant and animal diversity. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also be relevant to other viruses, such as HIV, that mutate and evade the immune system. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules, such as enzymes and receptors. Our results also provide a proof of concept for the application of deep learning to the optimization of other protein molecules.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that, contrary to some previous work, population size does not enhance CCE. In fact, the greater variation participants had access to in the larger populations may have overwhelmed their working memory and weakened their ability to selectively copy the best-adapted plane(s). We conclude that larger populations do not enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology, the evolution of intelligence, and the evolution of culture. They also have implications for the design of experiments and the interpretation of results. This work is a step toward a better understanding of the conditions under which larger population sizes enhance CCE. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor for AD. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk. APOE is also a major protein of astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain. We found that APOE isoform regulates the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse pruning, whereas APO4 decreases it. APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk, but the mechanism of this association is not known. We propose that APOE4 may be associated with increased AD risk because APOE4 accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, which may enhance synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is supported by the finding that APOE4 increases the accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses in the brain. The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of about 1,200 km. It is the densest part of the Earth, and its structure is one of the most mysterious parts of the planet. The core is thought to have formed by the solidification of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is more likely to occur than the nucleation of the close-packed hexagonal phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common features of marijuana abuse. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of marijuana on the brain and for the development of effective treatments for marijuana abuse. This article is protected by copyright. Language is a uniquely human skill, and the human brain is uniquely adapted to process language. Here, we use the most powerful artificial neural networks to study the language processing system in the human brain. We find that the most powerful models predict nearly 100% of the brain responses to sentences. Models’ fits to the next-word prediction task generalize to other datasets and imaging modalities. Model architecture appears to substantially contribute to neural fit. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that predictive processing may be a general mechanism for language comprehension in the human brain. This mechanism may be a target for the development of artificial intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning. However, it is still in its infancy and faces many challenges. One of the most fundamental challenges is the instability of DL algorithms. We show that this instability is not due to the lack of universality of DL algorithms, but rather due to the fact that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. Our results imply a classification theory describing conditions under which stable NNs can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results are a step toward the development of stable DL algorithms.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the pharmaceutical industry to develop a vaccine quickly enough, and the failure of the public to comply with public health measures. One of the most prominent arguments in favor of the latter failure is that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. We discuss the flaws of this experiment and show that it is not the public’s inability to understand exponential growth that is the problem.

Leprosy, or Hansen's disease, is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae. It is characterized by the loss of sensation and the formation of lepromatous and lepromatous-like lesions. In contrast, the reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon is characterized by the formation of diffuse, nonlesional, and nonpigmented lesions. Here, we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, a pathogen that causes these two distinct lesions. Phylogenetic and comparative genomic analyses suggest that M. lepromatosis is more closely related to the MRCA than M. leprae, and a Bayesian dating analysis suggests that they diverged from their MRCA approximately 13.9 Mya. Thus, despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also intimately related, as they are both captured by the entropy. However, the evolution of entanglement in isolated systems is not known in general. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is a consequence of integrability. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, which is solvable by the Bethe ansatz. Our result is a step toward a deeper understanding of the interplay between entanglement and thermodynamics. It also has implications for the study of quantum quenches, which are a paradigmatic example of isolated quantum systems.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The only currently available vaccine is based on the replication-defective adenovirus vector. However, the vector is not able to replicate in the human body, and therefore, it cannot provide the immune system with the opportunity to generate a protective immune response. In this work, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is able to replicate in the human body and, therefore, can provide the immune system with the opportunity to generate a protective immune response. The vaccine is temperature sensitive, which allows for the production of large quantities of the vaccine in a temperature-controlled environment. The vaccine is able to protect animals from the disease caused by the wild-type virus. The vaccine is currently in phase I/II clinical trials. This article is protected by copyright. Plague, caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. Today, most human plague cases are caused by rodent fleas, but this was not always the case. In this study, we show that human ectoparasite vectors, such as human fleas or body lice, were the primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries), including the Black Death (1347–1353). Our results challenge the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also provides a new perspective on the history of plague, which is a disease that has been studied for centuries. It is a reminder that the history of plague is still being written. The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is still poorly understood. We show that the evolution of brain neuronal density is not only important in its own right but also has important implications for the evolution of brain size. We also show that the evolution of brain neuronal density is not a simple function of brain size.

We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton. They are dynamic, and their structure and function are regulated by a variety of proteins. One of the most important proteins of this family is cofilin, which is responsible for the disassembly of actin filaments. However, cofilin’s function is not understood in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that mechanical stress enhances cofilin binding, but surprisingly, it has no effect on cofilin’s ability to sever filaments. We propose a simple model, which is supported by our experiments, that explains how mechanical stress enhances cofilin’s severing ability. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of cofilin in cancer and other diseases. They also have implications for understanding the role of mechanical stress in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is known to be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. However, the mechanisms underlying this effect are unknown. We show that fructose ingestion results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes greater hunger and desire for food and a willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. Our results have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and type 2 diabetes. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East, suggesting a recent settlement of Madagascar. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the Indian Ocean. It also provides a framework to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. Emotional contagion is the process by which people experience the same emotions as others. It is well established in laboratory experiments, but the results are controversial in the real world. We use a large real-world social network to test whether emotional contagion occurs outside of in-person interaction between individuals. We find that when people see positive expressions on Facebook, they produce more positive expressions, and when they see negative expressions, they produce more negative expressions. These results suggest that people are influenced by the emotions they see on Facebook, and that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion. The observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. (PsycINFO Database Record

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of protein in all organisms. The ribosome, a large molecular machine, reads the mRNA sequence and translates it into a protein. The ribosome is composed of two subunits, the large and small, and the mRNA is bound to the ribosome during translation. The mRNA sequence can be modified, and one of the most common modifications is the pseudouridine (Ψ) modification. Ψ is found in the coding region of the mRNA, and we show that the presence of Ψ can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings have implications for understanding the role of Ψ in mRNA function and for the development of translation-based therapies. (Read more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive health and well-being outcomes. This finding has important implications for the design of health promotion interventions, which should aim to increase the sense that life is filled with worthwhile activities. The results also have implications for the design of social care and support services for older people, which should aim to increase the sense that life is filled with worthwhile activities. The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known pattern in biology. However, the drivers of this pattern remain unclear. We use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and examination of the fossil record to test the role of energetic constraints in driving the evolution of aquatic mammal body sizes. We find that the evolution of aquatic mammals toward a size attractor is consistent with energetic constraints on body size. These results suggest that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of body size in mammals and may have implications for understanding the evolution of body size in other aquatic organisms. (Show more)

The common cold is one of the most common and economically devastating diseases in the world. Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. Rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature of 37 °C. We show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibit a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. This correlates with higher expression levels of type I and type III IFN genes and IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) at 37 °C. Rhinovirus replication is enhanced at 37 °C, and genetic deficiency of MAVS or the type I IFN receptor in infected airway cells partially rescues the temperature-dependent growth phenotype. These findings suggest that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is, at least in part, due to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. This may be a general mechanism for the temperature-dependent growth of many viruses. (Read more)

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense surfaces. This mechanism is used to regulate the activity of a chemosensory system that regulates the production of virulence factors and biofilm formation. The results also suggest that the pili are mechanosensitive, and that a mechanochemical model can explain the observed behavior. This work provides insight into the evolution of bacterial mechanosensitivity and the regulation of surface-induced gene expression. It also has implications for the development of new antibiofilm strategies. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the presence of pesticides in surface water and the risk for adverse effects on aquatic biodiversity. Our results show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has spread to more than 210 countries and territories, resulting in more than 5 million deaths. Deer are susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection, and experimentally infected fawns can transmit the virus. We report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in 33% of free-living deer and 82.5% of deer sampled during the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We also highlight the urgent need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. The hydropower industry is moving toward more sustainable practices. However, the proliferation of large dams in developing countries is a major challenge. This paper examines the challenges of building large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a global health crisis. The disease is believed to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and tau tangles, but the role of the immune system in AD pathogenesis has been largely overlooked. Here, we show that neurons are the primary source of inflammatory factors in AD, and that the accumulation of soluble Aβ species is the primary driver of this response. Our findings have important implications for the development of novel AD therapies, since they suggest that the immune system may be a viable target for treatment. This work also provides a potential explanation for the presence of a “preclinical” phase in AD, where the disease is not yet evident but the brain is burdened with Aβ. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a key player in the earliest stages of AD. © 2018, The Author(s).

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. The earliest evidence for the domestic chicken comes from the second millennium B.C.E. in Mesopotamia. However, the question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. The results reported here are part of a program to study the folding of a large protein in great detail. The protein studied is maltose binding protein (MBP), which is a two-domain protein of 370 residues. The results show that the folding of MBP is a multistage process. The folding is fast, but the process is not instantaneous. The folding intermediates are distinct, and the folding pathway is not unique.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to RNA caps, which are required for their biological activity. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap of Np4-capped RNAs is also capable of removing the cap of capped transcripts that are not Np4-capped. This enzyme, which is normally inactivated by stress, is able to deprotect capped transcripts because of a unique mechanism of recognition that results in the generation of a 1-nucleotide-long RNA product. This finding has important implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress. (Read more)

The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main mechanism of immune dysfunction is the depletion of lymphocytes. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore lymphocyte function and decrease immunosuppression. We tested this hypothesis in a mouse model of sepsis and demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This article is protected by copyright. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time and space, and the system’s dynamics are self-organized to a critical state. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity, which is the hallmark of criticality. The sandpile model is the first and archetypical model of SOC. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a sandpile model with continuous dynamics, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We describe the connection between our model and pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its bandgap is difficult to tune. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This work provides opportunities for diamond to be used in electronic and photonic applications. It also provides a general strategy for the control of electronic and phonon properties of other materials. This work is expected to promote the development of new materials and applications. The discovery of antimicrobial peptides in animals has led to the development of a new class of antibiotics. However, the discovery of antimicrobial peptides in plants is still in its infancy. In this work, we report the discovery of a plant antimicrobial peptide, NCR044, which exhibits potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The structure of the peptide was solved by NMR spectroscopy, and it was found to be highly dynamic and largely disordered. The peptide binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides, and its mode of action involves cell wall binding, penetration of the cell membrane, and accumulation in the cytoplasm and nucleoli of germlings. The discovery of this peptide provides a new avenue for the development of a new class of plant fungicides. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sperm are the only cells that are transferred directly from the male to the female during sexual reproduction. Because sperm are the only cells that are transferred from the male to the female, it is likely that sperm are exposed to a variety of female-derived molecules. However, the extent to which these molecules are involved in the life history of sperm is largely unknown. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple female-derived proteins associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, helping to control bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that platelets and VWF are in a dynamic equilibrium, with the A1 domain of VWF in one state when platelets are not flowing, and in a different state when platelets are flowing. The state of VWF is switched by flow, and the switch is reversible. The switch is important for VWF function.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense research in recent years. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that interact with humans, has been much less studied. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, with over 45,000 unique virus taxa identified. The resource is used to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results provide a foundation for future studies of the human virome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the observational capability is inadequate. In this paper, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), which can provide high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds. The HSRL observations over Beijing show that the aerosol loading increased the water cloud droplet number concentration and decreased the droplet effective radius. However, the aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. We expect that the results of this study will be of interest to the climate science community.

The evolution of life is intimately linked to the evolution of the environment. In this paper, we use the thermostability of ancestral enzymes to reconstruct the paleoenvironment of ancient organisms. We show that the surface environment of the earliest organisms was warmer than previously thought, and that this warm surface environment has persisted through time. This work provides a new perspective on the evolution of life on Earth.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate entry into the host, but the mechanism of invasion is poorly understood. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host cell, which is critical for invasion. This finding has major implications for the design of new anti-malarial drugs and vaccines. It also suggests that the parasite and host cell are in a dynamic equilibrium, with parasite-derived forces working in tandem with host cell forces to facilitate invasion. This is a major conceptual change in our understanding of the invasion process. (Show more)

However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its bandgap is difficult to tune. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks are associated with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host defense and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. We also show that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of ambient humidity on host defense and disease outcome, which may be useful for the development of strategies to reduce the impact of influenza virus infection. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in the form of a tree, with each word in a sentence being part of a different branch. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures is unknown. Here, we show that the brain responds to each word in a sentence with a sudden increase in high-gamma power, followed by a sudden decrease whenever words can be merged into a phrase. The timing and magnitude of these responses were consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based on sequential transition probabilities, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is consistent with the idea that the brain uses a bottom-up or left-corner parser to build syntactic structures. Our findings may help to advance the study of language in the brain.

Wnt signaling is a major pathway in development. Axin is a key component of the signaling pathway. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We also show that the two forms of Axin are regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of redundant genes. It also provides a new perspective on the regulation of redundant genes.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain involved in the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We have characterized the circuit that mediates this effect. Stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to pick up food and eat for the remainder of the stimulation period. We found that stimulation-induced eating is dependent on dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra. We also found that stimulation-induced eating is dependent on neurons in the LH that project to the ventral tegmental area and that these neurons are themselves dependent on neurons in the locus coeruleus. Finally, we found that stimulation-induced eating is not dependent on neurons in the LH that project to the periaqueductal gray. Thus, we have characterized a circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This circuit is not involved in the hunger or satiety mechanisms that govern normal feeding. The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and it is being rapidly deforested. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are used to monitor and deter deforestation, but the alerts are often generated too late to deter deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects are imprecise. The results suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to sense the presence and location of sound sources in their environment. The auditory organs of animals are all part of the organism, and the size of the auditory organs is constrained by the size of the organism. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without an auditory organ because its web acts as an acoustic antenna. The spider can hear in all directions, and the web can be used to hear from a distance. The spider can also adjust the size of the web to hear in different directions. The spider can also regenerate the web to hear in different directions. The spider is able to hear without an auditory organ, and the web can be used to hear without an auditory organ.

Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global health issues. We estimate the health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. We show that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. The chemical influence of air pollution on aeolian dust contributes to the aerosol cooling. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51 °C and all pollution particles 0.73 °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36 °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We report an engineered sequence variant of the RBD, which mediates viral entry to cells via ACE2. Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood. It is difficult to treat and has a poor prognosis. In the last years, it was discovered that some neuroblastoma patients have mutations in the gene encoding the proto-oncogene protein anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK). This discovery has led to the development of new therapeutic strategies. However, the mechanisms of action of ALK mutations are not fully understood. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK homologs are activated by secreted ALKALs and that this activation is required for the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Our results provide a new approach to study the role of ALK homologs in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroblastoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is one of the most important events in human history. However, the history of plague is poorly understood due to the lack of ancient genomic data. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a unique opportunity to explore the history of plague during this critical period of development. Our results suggest that plague was not a widespread disease in the Neolithic, and that it was only after the emergence of the flea-adapted form that it became a global pathogen. These data also reveal the importance of rapid dispersal and genetic drift in the evolution of plague. Together, these data provide a more complete picture of the history of plague. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we found that women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class hierarchies via candidate support. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems on the North American Great Plains is highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage and mineral-associated organic matter, but the magnitude of these effects is highly dependent on the type of crop and livestock system. These results highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We used a combination of expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify risk factors for spillover and spread of viruses in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. We validated the risk assessment using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world. The top 12 ranked viruses were known zoonotic viruses, including SARS-CoV-2. Several newly detected viruses ranked higher than known zoonotic viruses. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for the services they provide. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators and is often used as a proxy for the quality of the reward. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify the enzymes responsible for the production of this compound and show that the same enzymatic activities are likely to underlie the production of red nectar in hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. Our findings suggest that the red nectar trait is likely to be widespread in plants that depend on pollinators for reproduction. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The history of Europe is marked by complex demographic processes, which have shaped the genetic landscape of the continent. However, the history of the population during the period between the end of the last Ice Age and the early Middle Ages is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. The analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. The results also highlight the importance of functional variants in the study of the history of the population. © 2018, The Author(s).

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans and for developing effective countermeasures against future bat coronavirus threats to human health.

DNA replication is a fundamental process that is essential for the survival of all organisms. In eukaryotes, the lagging strand of DNA is replicated in short fragments called Okazaki fragments. The synthesis of these fragments is highly processive and requires the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) to maintain the polymerase holoenzyme in a stable association with the DNA. However, the stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. Here, we show that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results also suggest that the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme may be a key factor in the regulation of lagging strand replication. These findings have implications for understanding the role of pol δ in human disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. In this paper, we describe the first experimental demonstration of the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins.

Urban change is a major topic of urban studies. However, the physical dynamics of urban change are not well understood. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. We hope that our method and results will contribute to the development of urban studies.

COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment is mainly supportive. The current study shows that tocilizumab, which is effective in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, may be effective in the treatment of COVID-19. It is expected to provide a new treatment strategy for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic. The ability of fungi to sense and respond to copper is poorly understood. Here we show that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and impact cellular copper content. Xanthocillin-derived copper-binding metabolites are secreted and have antimicrobial properties, including inhibition of laccase activity. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These results suggest that the xan BGC is a source of fungal copper-binding metabolites that may be important for fungal health and interactions with microbes. This article is protected by copyright. Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is consistent with the presence of silicic volcanism in the region. The presence of tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in a sedimentary rock at Marias Pass, Gale crater, suggests that the sediment was sourced from the crater wall/rim/central peak region. The presence of amorphous precipitated silica, primary precipitates, and/or their diagenesis products in the sedimentary rock at Marias Pass, suggests that multiple aqueous solutions with variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities infiltrated the sediment source region and/or the sedimentary environment at the time of deposition. The presence of post lithification fracture/vein fill anhydrous sulfate in the sedimentary rock at Marias Pass, suggests that the sedimentary environment was a favorable environment for the formation of such minerals. Frost damage is a major threat to plant productivity, and the frequency of late-spring frosts (LSFs) is expected to increase in the future. However, the geographic distribution of LSFs and the evolutionary strategies of plants to minimize frost damage are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of LSFs is associated with the evolutionary strategies of plants, and that the latter are likely to be a major determinant of the future evolution of frost resistance. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this response is not well understood. We found that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These results have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. In particular, our findings suggest that the suppression of Th17 cells may be a useful therapeutic strategy for the treatment of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. This strategy would be most effective if it targeted the development of Th17 cells rather than their direct interaction with the intestinal epithelium. (Read more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is poorly understood. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and test potential therapies. The method is easily adaptable to other cell types, and the cells can be easily expanded in culture. This will enable the study of ALS disease mechanisms and the rapid testing of potential therapies. The method will also enable the production of motor neuron-like cells from other neurodegenerative diseases. This will be a powerful tool for ALS research. (Read more)

The gut microbiota of arthropods is an important factor in their health and fitness. However, the ways in which infectious agents influence the composition of the microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the tick Ixodes scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the transmission of the bacterium to the vector. We also show that the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the bacterial peptidoglycan cell wall, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which infectious agents influence the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitate transmission to vector hosts. They also provide a model for the use of antibacterial proteins by pathogens to alter the gut microbiota. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Birds are one of the most successful animal groups on Earth. However, the origin of the modern avian bauplan is still a matter of debate. Here, we describe a new basal member of the clade Pygostylia (birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone termed “pygostyle”). This new taxon, Jinguofortis perplexus, adds important information about the evolution of the avian tail and the origin of the modern avian bauplan.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of water vapor. In this paper, we show that water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the evolution of our climate. We also show that the water vapor in the stratosphere is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is a feedback that increases the sensitivity of the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. Some animals, such as frogs, are green, and this color is often associated with high concentrations of a pigment called biliverdin. The presence of high biliverdin concentrations in green animals is called chlorosis. In this study, we show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of frogs. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Our results provide evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. These findings may have important implications for understanding the evolution of color in vertebrates. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the mechanisms that regulate the hypoxic phenotype are not well understood. We show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, a demethylase that demethylates NANOG mRNA, which encodes a breast cancer stem cell factor. ALKBH5 expression is regulated by HIF-1α and HIF-2α, and is required for the hypoxic induction of breast cancer stem cell characteristics. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skin for parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. The term abortivum in Latin, used in many sources, has led some scholars to suggest that fetal skin was used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were produced from fetal skins, arguing instead for unexpected alternatives, such as rabbit. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a key parameter in understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle reorganization that preceded the extinction is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. The carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. The age model will also be used to evaluate the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Show more)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in the regulation of various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the role of RORα in the intestinal epithelium is not well understood. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and antiviral drugs. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in currently circulating strains. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation. We show that the mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion with the target membrane. This study provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the mutant virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is new even in the case of a single player.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites.
